verses.roman:
mainaṁ māyāvinaṁ dṛptaṁ
niraṅkuśam asattamam
ākrīḍa bālavad deva
yathāśīviṣam utthitam

synonyms: mā—do not; enam—him; māyā-vinam—skilled in conjuring tricks; dṛptam—arrogant; niraṅkuśam—self-sufficient; asat-tamam—most wicked; ākrīḍa—play with; bāla-vat—like a child; deva—O Lord; yathā—as; āśīviṣam—a serpent; utthitam—aroused.
translation: Lord Brahmā continued: My dear Lord, there is no need to play with this serpentine demon, who is always very skilled in conjuring tricks and is arrogant, self-sufficient and most wicked.

purport.content: No one is unhappy when a serpent is killed. It is a practice among village boys to catch a serpent by the tail and play with it for some time and then kill it. Similarly, the Lord could have killed the demon at once, but He played with him in the same way as a child plays with a snake before killing it. Brahmā requested, however, that since the demon was more wicked and undesirable than a serpent, there was no need to play with him. It was his wish that he be killed at once, without delay.
